proxyLocation: top-centre of the table in snapshot 1
utilizationMethod: Grip the narrow neck of the bottle between thumb and first two fingers as if it were the wooden handle. The much heavier, forward-projecting body of the bottle supplies a clear forward-loaded torque when you tilt it, closely mimicking the mug’s centre-of-mass behaviour. Raise and rotate the bottle just as you would tip the virtual mug toward your mouth.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: This mug serves as a drinking vessel, designed to be grasped by the handle
virtualObjectInfo.inertia: User should feel the center of mass located significantly forward from the handle grip point
virtualObjectInfo.outline: User should feel a relatively thin, slender rod approximately 2 cm in diameter. User should sense the handle's curved arc and rounded cross-section.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: Users will approach the mug’s thin, 2-cm-diameter wooden handle with a precision–to-small-power grip (thumb on one side, index and middle fingers wrapping the opposite side, ring finger optionally supporting). The hand starts in neutral orientation, then closes until the fingertips seat against the rounded wooden contour. Once secured, the forearm flexes and the wrist pronates/supinates to raise the body of the mug to the mouth. Because the mug’s mass is located forward of the grip point, the user will feel a forward torque that increases as the mug is tilted; the wrist compensates by exerting counter-torque. After drinking, the user can swirl or tilt the mug, producing noticeable inertial lag from the liquid mass. If the mug is set down, the grasp relaxes and the handle is released; no deformation or squeeze feedback is expected because the wooden mug stays rigid. Overall, the interaction is dominated by a stable, lightly textured wooden handle, forward-loaded weight, and smooth, wrist-driven tilting motion.

proxyLocation: upper left quadrant of snapshot 1
utilizationMethod: Pinch the black plastic cap as the “handle” between thumb and fingers while letting the soft metal tube dangle forward. Although lighter than a real mug, the squeezeable tube hangs and flops, still giving a sense of an offset mass that must be stabilised when you tilt it.

proxyLocation: upper right quadrant of snapshot 1
utilizationMethod: Hook your index finger around one of the rabbit’s ears like a curved handle and support the body with your thumb. The bulk of the rabbit’s body projects forward from that grip point, so rotating your wrist provides the same feeling of forward torque that a filled mug would create.

physicalObject: black Tesla-branded insulated water bottle with silver lid
proxyLocation: standing upright near the top-center of snapshot 1
utilizationMethod: Grasp the bottle close to its base with a full power grip; the long cylindrical body fills the palm like an axe handle. Swing the bottle so the heavier, capped end becomes the "axe head," making the mass feel slightly top-weighted and providing noticeable inertia during chopping motions.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: This axe serves as a chopping tool
virtualObjectInfo.inertia: User should feel significant mass with pronounced head-heavy inertia.
virtualObjectInfo.outline: User should feel a cylindrical and substantial grip that requires a firm grasp around the handle's circumference.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: The axe is grasped with a full power grip around the cylindrical wooden handle, typically with one hand near the end of the shaft for maximum leverage, or with two hands (dominant low, support hand high) for larger swings. Fingers wrap completely while the thumb either coils around or lies along the handle. The user lifts the axe by extending the elbow/shoulder; then executes overhead or diagonal chopping arcs driven by the shoulders and torso. During the swing the blade-heavy head produces strong forward inertia, creating pronounced pull at the end of the arc and a perceptible pivot about the user’s wrist. Upon simulated impact, the axe should decelerate abruptly while the handle transmits a short vibration, but the virtual handle itself remains rigid and unchanged in outline. Fine manipulation, such as repositioning or inspecting, involves regripping closer to the head with a lighter power grip and small wrist rotations.

proxyLocation: upper left quadrant of snapshot 1 lying flat
utilizationMethod: Hold the crimped metal rear section between thumb and fingers as though it were a miniature handle. While weight is minimal, the soft metal lets you practice finger-wrapped regripping and small wrist rotations used when inspecting or repositioning the axe close to its head.

proxyLocation: center bottom of snapshot 2

virtualObjectInfo.usage: This axe serves as a chopping tool
virtualObjectInfo.inertia: User should feel significant mass with pronounced head-heavy inertia.
virtualObjectInfo.outline: User should feel a cylindrical and substantial grip that requires a firm grasp around the handle's circumference.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: The axe is grasped with a full power grip around the cylindrical wooden handle, typically with one hand near the end of the shaft for maximum leverage, or with two hands (dominant low, support hand high) for larger swings. Fingers wrap completely while the thumb either coils around or lies along the handle. The user lifts the axe by extending the elbow/shoulder; then executes overhead or diagonal chopping arcs driven by the shoulders and torso. During the swing the blade-heavy head produces strong forward inertia, creating pronounced pull at the end of the arc and a perceptible pivot about the user’s wrist. Upon simulated impact, the axe should decelerate abruptly while the handle transmits a short vibration, but the virtual handle itself remains rigid and unchanged in outline. Fine manipulation, such as repositioning or inspecting, involves regripping closer to the head with a lighter power grip and small wrist rotations.

physicalObject: metallic silver pen or fine-tip marker
proxyLocation: right of center in snapshot 2
utilizationMethod: Clasp the pen close to its capped end, leaving most of its length forward. Though light, its slender cylindrical shape matches an axe handle’s contour, letting users practice precise finger wrapping and controlled angle adjustments when ‘inspecting’ the tool.

proxyLocation: standing upright at the top-center of Snapshot 1
utilizationMethod: Grasp the bottle 2–3 cm above its base so that most of the mass (filled liquid + metal cap) sits forward of the hand. This creates a mild head-heavy feel and the cylindrical body gives the fingers a firm, full power-grip similar to a hammer handle. Swing the wrist in short arcs; the inertia of the bottle reproduces the weighted head sensation.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: This hammer serves as a striking tool
virtualObjectInfo.inertia: User should feel significant mass concentrated in the head, creating a distinctly head-heavy sensation when wielding the hammer.
virtualObjectInfo.outline: User should feel a cylindrical and substantial grip that requires a firm grasp around the handle's circumference.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: Users wrap their fingers and thumb in a firm power grip around the hammer’s cylindrical handle. Typical usage places the dominant hand 2–3 cm from the butt end for maximum moment arm; for precision taps the grip may slide closer to the head. Swinging is predominantly wrist-driven with supplementary elbow flexion—short, rapid arcs for nail-like strikes or full shoulder arcs for heavy blows. The head-heavy mass causes perceptible centrifugal pull that stabilizes the handle’s orientation during motion. At impact the head should appear to stop suddenly while the user feels a high-frequency jolt through the virtual handle. Because the handle is rigid, no squeezing deformation is expected; however, slight micro-repositioning of the fingers may occur between strikes for comfort and angle adjustment.

physicalObject: black Tesla-branded insulated water bottle with silver lid
proxyLocation: top-center of the white table in Snapshot 1
utilizationMethod: Grasp the bottle around its lower cylindrical body as you would the wooden handle of the sickle. Point the heavier, metal-capped end forward and slightly inward; the cap’s extra mass creates a modest forward-weighted inertia that mimics the sickle’s curved blade during sweeping, hook-like motions.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: This sickle serves as a harvesting and cutting tool
virtualObjectInfo.inertia: User should feel moderate forward-weighted inertia concentrated in the curved blade, but distributed along the arc rather than at a single point.
virtualObjectInfo.outline: User should feel a cylindrical grip that requires a firm grasp around the handle's circumference.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: The sickle is held in a closed power grip around its short wooden handle, with the blade’s concave edge projecting forward and slightly inward. The user’s wrist pronates and supinates to orient the curved blade, then executes sweeping, hooking motions driven from the elbow and wrist—pulling the blade through virtual vegetation. The forward-distributed mass of the arced blade produces moderate but continuous inertial bias toward the cutting edge, so the wrist senses a gentle forward-left (for right-handed users) tug during each swing. Fine tasks, such as repositioning or inspecting, involve subtle wrist rolls while maintaining the same power grip. The handle remains rigid and unchanged in outline; no deformation feedback is needed, but users may expect mild vibration or drag feedback when the virtual blade meets resistance.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: This sickle serves as a harvesting and cutting tool

virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: The sickle is held in a closed power grip around its short wooden handle, with the blade’s concave edge projecting forward and slightly inward. The user’s wrist pronates and supinates to orient the curved blade, then executes sweeping, hooking motions driven from the elbow and wrist—pulling the blade through virtual vegetation. The forward-distributed mass of the arced blade produces moderate but continuous inertial bias toward the cutting edge, so the wrist senses a gentle forward-left (for right-handed users) tug during each swing. Fine tasks, such as repositioning or inspecting, involve subtle wrist rolls while maintaining the same power grip. The handle remains rigid and unchanged in outline; no deformation feedback is needed, but users may expect mild vibration or drag feedback when the virtual blade meets resistance.
